author: R Sujatha
text:
It will prevent students from using mobile phones, other gadgets for copying

University Grants Commission has decided to allow universities to deploy low-powered jammers in examination halls to prevent students using mobile phones, bluetooth and other gadgets for copying.

In a notice to all universities, UGC Secretary Jaspal S. Sandhu said that the government had a policy to provide the jammers on lease in order to prevent unfair means used through radio frequency-based devices.

And that the jammers could be procured only from the ECIL and the BELUGC Vice-Chairman H. Devaraj told The Hindu that the decision to permit universities to use jammers followed complaint from a medical university that students carried mobile phones into exam hall and had used it for copying. In 2012, a case came up in the Madras High Court stating that two students of Government Stanley Medical College had copied using a mobile phone. The college sought the help of Cyber Crime officials to prove that they used bluetooth. One student was barred from taking the exam for three subsequent sessions.

The universities can’t procure jammers on their own due to

security reasons
title: Varsities can use jammers in exam halls
